title: The lid is thin and cheap, lets the cold escape giving you wet cubes
text:
[[VIDEOID:5a3f6b4ad2e4e41e8ae786900d579a60]] We use portable ice machines all the time and have for a decade. Our tiny refrigerator/freezer has no room to put ice cube trays. We used to buy ice, but long ago went with portable ice machines. They meet our need perfectly.

The manufacturers all seem to be making them cheaper and cheaper. Our first ice machine lasted over 4 years. Every subsequent machine has given out at only one year (or less). Our last one decided to die last month. We got about a year and a half from that one (after the company replaced the first one, which was a lemon). So, I found myself shopping for ice machines again.

This machine has a very high rating and lots of reviews. The average review is pretty posotive with high stars given. I read the comments about wet ice, but thought maybe these folks had not previously used portable ice machines before (they do not make super hard cubes).
Nope, they were right.

We let this machine sit for 2 days after opening (a little longer than the mfg suggests) to make sure all oil levels were properly settled. We added water to the fill line and waited for the magic. It makes cubes well. We dumped out the first entire batch of cubes from the initial water batch and had run the self-cleaning option. The cubes looked ok.

So now we were ready to make ice to actually use. We only use bottled water, as we have hard water here.

Now, the machine itself is very nice looking.
It is more vertical than our previous machines. The overall footprint is smaller, BUT it is taller as well. That is something to consider if you plan on putting it under a counter or shelf. Be sure to leave plenty of air circulation around it as well. We chose the red one. The color is great.

It takes a bit longer to make a batch of ice than other machines we have had. But after using it for a week, I can tell you EXACTLY why the ice cubes are wet with this model.

While the rest of the machine seems decent, the LID is made of the thinnest, cheapest plastic I've ever seen on one of these machines. Have you ever bought disposable plastic stemware for the holidays? Those are thicker. You can hold your hand near any part of the lid, and you can feel the cold air flowing OUT. No insulation in the lid whatsoever. Most models have a sturdy lid with a smaller window where you can see if the ice is ready. It helps keep the cold INSIDE the machine as much as possible. Not this machine!

Portable ice machines don't keep ice frozen forever, of course, but they at least keep it a few hours. Not this model. It starts melting as soon as it hits the basket. And why not? This poorly-constructed lid is the equivalent of putting a piece of saran wrap over the ice!! Wait - nope, saran wrap would keep the cold in better too.
And because it is so thin, you'll need to be careful about just letting the lid drop down after you get ice out. It is pretty fragile. But what a horrible design/material choice for an otherwise-nice machine. If these were inexpensive appliances, I might not mind so much. But they are not cheap, and I no longer have a lot of "play" in my budget for these types of purchases.

The ice comes out frozen as hard as any of our machines have done. BUT, the thin lid lets cold air out and room temp air IN. The ice immediately starts to melt, making for very wet cubes that then stick together in a clump. And I'm not talking about the standard slightly-damp cubes of any portable ice maker - I am talking full out wet, due to the lid offering ZERO temperature protection or insulation. VERY disappointing.

So this machine is a hard pass from me. (I have tried to start the return process, which I have 2 months to do, but it isn't letting me complete it for whatever reason.)

Anyway, this is our 5th portable ice machine in 10 years. I hope it lasts quite a while, but not holding my breath. I really, truly recommend going with a different machine. This one is just poorly designed.

title: Mine sounds possessed!  Growls and grunts. NOT NORMAL
text:
UPDATE as of July 2020 -

We ended up having to move last year, so only used this ice maker for about two months before packing it back up in its original packaging for a local move. It didn't get UNpacked until three months ago. We plugged it back in, ran a few rounds of lemon water through it to clean out the tubes, and got it going. Things seemed fine. It wasn't even as noisy as it was before. We only use bottled water in it, as our area has pretty hard water. But then last week, it suddenly decided it wasn't going to make ice any more. It was giving us the "add water" error message, even though it was full. We tried turning it off and back on several times. We also completely unplugged it, hoping that might reset whatever had gone wrong.
Nope.
Dead ice maker.

So, we got LESS THAN SIX MONTHS' use from this ice maker. I don't know if it was just a lemon (you can read my original review...it never sounded right, and I never got a response from Frigidaire), or if this company makes extra-cheap machines. I am beyond disappointed in this. I need an ice maker and now can't afford to replace this one, with so little use on it.
Not happy.
------------
ORIGINAL REVIEW -
We've had two other ice machines over the last decade. We keep this upstairs. I am partially disabled and don't have the mobility to run to the kitchen fridge. These machines help me have cold drinks and fill ice bags.

I love the color on this one. We've not had the Frigidare brand before, but most of these portable ice makers are the same and just have a different label slapped on them. It is pictured in the photo (decal was ours, they do not come thay way).

This is making ice ok for now, but I am SERIOUSLY concerned about how long it will last! We have NEVER had one that sounded like it was on its last leg, gasping and grunting to get the water up into the freezing compartment! It grunts and grinds so loudly, it makes the overflow tray on our keurig coffee maker (maybe 1-1/2 to 2 feet from the ice maker) shake! It is like a mini earthquake when it pumps water up! I KNOW this is not normal. At first, we thought the coffee pot was dying and grunting, as we listened from the other room. Nope...it was this ice maker.

I would like to see either the seller or manufacturer step up and replace this machine for us. We bought it new, not a refurb. Very disappointed in this unit so far. But I can no longer afford to just get a different one. 😓

title: Wouldn't work right out of the box.
text:
Wow. Just wow.
This machine arrived today. We set it up, and let it sit for four hours to let the fluids settle. The directions say two hours, but we got busy and it was four hours later.

I rinsed off the machine's insides with a soft cloth before first use. Then I filled it with water and a little lemon juice. The reservoir holds a lot more water than our old machine...
I plugged it in and turned on the power. The power light goes green and I can select small or large cubes (the booklet says you can choose from three sizes, but there's only two).

That's the end of the success.
The "ice full" light came on immediately without it ever pulling up any water. The area with the ice prongs ACTS like it is going to bring in water (and it did bring in a little bit, not a full load the first time and immediately dumped it back into the reservoir), but then it doesn't really do a thing, goes through the dumping motion and the "ice full" light flips on.

So, dug out the little book that came with it. Troubleshooting says it is one of two things: either the water sensors are dirty and you should clean them, or you should use cold water or add ice to the reservoir if the room temps are above 80º (? Or 85º). So, in other words, the machine that was in our home for less than five hours already needs cleaned, OR I need to only use it during cool weather???

This is ridiculous and this hunk of trash is going back.
I cannot believe no one tests any of these things before sending them to customers. The one I bought says "Igloo" in the description and "RCA" on the front and in the photo. Quite frankly, RCA products are bad, but I thought in this case, it was just the label, as it seems at least six different sellers have the exact same machines.

Avoid.
Save up and get a better one. I just want some ice in the bedroom...I don't want to become an ice maker mechanic to get a few cubes.

All thumbs DOWN.

title: Mixed blessing, but so far, so good
text:
I looked at probably 20 portable ice makers before choosing this one.
Price was a factor, but so was customer input from reviews. It seemed like many of the other models were the exact same machine with a different company label stuck on them, and their reviews were so varied, it seemed like you either got a lemon or a good one.

Also, all the others opened at the top and vented on the side. For some reason, I thought this one would work better in our area, with the drawer pulling out at the front, and I THOUGHT the vent would be at the side like all the other machines.

My purpose in buying this is not for a bar or camper, like many people. I am partially disabled, and can't get downstairs to the kitchen on any sort of regular basis. I really wanted to be able to have ice when I wanted some, especially with the heat of summer rolling in very, very soon. I don't like room temperature drinks, esp water or tea, so I'd found myself drinking Pepsi almost exclusively, the only thing I could stand at room temp. That needed to stop!

So, I ended up buying this one, but the experience was not a pleasant one. I love my Amazon prime dearly, but they really botched this one. The shipping dates got moved around even after I paid extra for one-day shipping, and ended up with this being delivered on a totally different day, when I was the only one home and could not come to the door. (Note that Amazon did end up giving me a small credit on my acct to try to make up for the shipping problem, even though it did not solve my problem.) I always chat with the UPS guys through the upstairs window, so they left it for me anyway. I knew my son would be home very shortly after, and he was. He brought the box up, and I have to say that I am almost positive I got a customer return. The box looked like it had previous shipping labels peeled off of it. The box was beat up, torn, and had a crushed in spot on the side. Our UPS guys are really great, so I think it was shipped out from Day One looking like that - who in the warehouses think customers really want something that looks that bad?! (And yes, I know this is a product review section, and I can file shipping problems elsewhere, and I will. Just giving folks a heads-up of how it is shipped and what I received.) This is shipped in its original mfg box with tie cords on it, there is no other packaging other than what the mfg sends it out with - no Amazon packaging whatsoever. Strike One.

I opened the box, not sure of what I would find. It only has two big strips of styrofoam on the sides to hold it.
Ours indeed had a dent in the side, and one of the back exhaust fans had cracked plastic. Not a crisis, but at this price, I really do expect a brand new item in great condition! Strike Two.

SMELLS/TASTE: I read a lot of reviews that talk about the plastic smell and/or taste in the cubes, and how it didn't seem to want to fire up well. IF someone reads the directions (not everyone likes to do that!), you'd see it says to make sure the machine sits for at least an hour to allow the coolant to properly settle back into place after you unpack it. This particular model also says to run a bleach solution through it to help clean it. I DO NOT RECOMMEND THAT!! The machine indeed smells heavily of plastic. Anyone who has had a relay switch burn out on an item knows what smell I am talking about - sort of like melting plastic. Ugh. However, having read plenty about portable ice makers before buying one, I knew that either vinegar or lemon juice would also work just fine. I chose to go with one that was ingestible, rather than bleach!! We did the lemon juice, and ran an entire cycle of cubes through it with the lemon/water. (Toss the ice please!) I then ran two loads (all the cubes a full water tank would make) through it of plain water. AFTER those cycles, I wiped it out again and ran regular water through it to try making cubes we'd use. We had no problems at all with any funny tastes in our ice this way. If you have a bad quality of tap water though, I'd suggest using either bottled, filtered or distilled water. It is only natural that your cubes will not taste better than your tap water. Ours is okay, so we're good that way. I would have bought a water filter (like a Brita) if that had not been the case. No lemony taste, no plastic taste, no gross tastes or odors at all. (Remember, I really do NOT recommend using bleach like the mfg suggests. While I understand the germ-killing properties of the bleach, I really don't want to ingest any of it. I would also think it would be much more caustic to the plastic parts and hoses of the machine, wearing them out sooner. Stick with lemon juice.) It did smell like plastic out the exhaust fan for quite a while, but it is fading away.

NOISE: Of course it is going to make noise. This has a compressor, and it will be making some noise. However, I've found that at its noisiest part of the cycle, it is no different than a microwave oven running, sometimes a little quieter.The ice cubes dumping make me jump a little bit, at least at first, but then again I am easily startled. Made the cats jump too! LOL! However, they are pretty much used to it now, even if they eyeball it suspiciously while it is running.

I have to say that I haven't stopped to time an actual cycle to make the ice. I've tried the small, medium and large cubes though. They are all gumdrop-shaped (or like the Dots candy at the movies), with a hole in the middle of the bottom. It didn't seem to take very long though. The small ones were a little too small for my uses, but would be good for smaller drink glasses. I use a [[ASIN:B003X46LHG Bubba Brands Keg 52 Oz Mug Slate Gray]] to hold the ice at the moment, and love it. If you use the medium size, you can get the first batch in around 10 minutes, but the other batches do seem to take longer for some reason. It has also seemed to get "stuck" where it runs and runs, with nothing going on. I turn it off, let it sit a minute and push start again, and off it goes. I am not sure if it is just my machine with the dents from rough handling, or if all of this model is like that.

I was disappointed that this unit does not exhaust on the side, reason being where I planned to locate it, on a table behind my bed! It would vent towards my pillow, which is just not gonna happen. So, I have it turned sideways so it will vent towards the doorway. It makes opening the ice drawer more awkward, and makes me wish I'd tried one of the top-opening models now. There wasn't anything in the photos and such to suggest that this unit would be different than most of the other portable ice makers. It is. I'll post photos at a later date.

This model's book also suggests plugging the machine in to a GFI outlet, or grounded plug that will shut off if it senses dampness. I don't have one in the bedroom, and currently am using a heavy-duty, three-prong extension cord and plugging it in in the bathroom, where we do have a GFI plug. Not ideal, but better than trying to get a special outlet installed in a rented bedroom.

The scoop is VERY tiny. It works best to scoop towards you, so you don't send ice cubes back into the machine.
The measuring cup works well for pouring, because you have a small reservoir to fill, and you have to go over a small clear rubber "wall" that helps to hold the drawer in place and hold temperatures.

Any unused ice does indeed melt back into the reservoir and is recycled back into cubes. Once I have enough ice for anyone who wants it, I turn it off rather than let it continually cycle. I also unplug it in the evenings when I go to bed for the night, since I'm the only one who can't go downstairs for ice if they want it. I hope that saves on the "vampire electricity" of the unit. Note that this is not a refrigerated ice maker, and the unused ice WILL melt. Many people complained about ice cubes stuck together - I've only experienced that when getting ice that has been done for an hour or so (it keeps the ice for at least an hour after the last cycle at this point) - otherwise, the cubes are all loose and easy to use. If you try to take the ice drawer all the way out after leaving the ice sit for a while, it WILL leak water on you - the water is simply the ice melting back and going through the drain holes that let it run back into the reservoir. (Nope - I didn't even think about the drainage holes when I pulled the drawer out the first time, and had water on the table and the floor. That was my fault though.)

For now, I am mostly happy with it. I cannot tell you how nice it is to have ice when I want it, instead of waiting for someone to get home in the evening and get me some! It was an expensive luxury though, and one I really thought long and hard about getting since I can no longer work. I'm thinking I really want to keep it. The cosmetic issues were VERY annoying, since I paid for a new machine, not a used one, but in this case, I blame Amazon for sending this out with a crushed box from the get-go. I would not have accepted it, had I been able to get to the door and saw it. Again - for some reason, this was the most problematic purchase I've ever had in all my time on Amazon.

This machine has not reached Strike Three yet, but you can be sure I'll come back and update my review should that happen. For now, I'll keep running it, and see how it seems to work, dents, cracked exhaust grid and all. (The dents are even more annoying, because it has a stainless steel appearance. It shows readily. It was more of a hassle to return it than to just keep it, as long as it continues to work.)

UPDATE June 29, 2012:
Well, I've had this machine for a little over a month now. Is it perfect? Nope. Does it make ice?
Yep. Does it make a little noise? Yep, but not unbearable.
So far, the broken parts do not seem to be affecting the basic function of the machine.
While I still have not literally timed the cube cycle (I have good intentions, but seems like there's always
something better to do than watch the clock for ice cubes to drop! Ha!), I have found the medium cubes to be the most useful. In fact, I often use an empty Sobe Lifewater bottle to make quick tea (loving the new tea from Lipton with the honey in it), and the medium cubes fit in this bottle perfectly. So, that might give folks a better idea about the size of the medium cube. The difference in the sizes are basically more (or less) layers of ice on the cubes. The small ones are still too big for a basic 16.9 oz water bottle, and melt too fast when I shake up my tea.
The first batch of the day takes around 10 minutes, but for some reason, they are skinnier than the normal mediums. The machine makes additional batches inbetween 10-15 minutes. Around 2 or 2-1/2 of the water cup it comes with to fill the reservoir to maximum. That will fill the ice bin to the top with medium cubes.

At this point, I increased my stars by one, because of the function of the machine, and it being willing to
do what I "hired" it to do - keep me in cold drinks. Strike three has not yet happened, and I hope it doesn't!
Enjoy!

title: Wish I had read here first...
text:
I didn't want to rate with any stars, because I have a slightly different model, FR464, but
I think that refers to the color too.However, I can't leave a review without a star rating.
We bought an Igloo 4.9 cu ft fridge in black (FR464) from another website.
It is very, very close to this model, so I want to share our Igloo experience.

First off, the site had the wrong photos of the insides, so I didn't get the freezer I wanted.
While I suppose this was a site issue, it could have also been sent that way from Igloo.
I don't know, but I only got a 1/2-width freezer instead of one the full width of the fridge.

Pros:
Looks great in the room.
Plenty of door storage.
Reasonably quiet.

Cons:
Does not keep things very cold in a warm environment.
Shelves not very adjustable - you are stuck with a shallow shelf at the bottom.
It will hold a 16.9 oz bottle of water on its side, and that's it.
Freezer is not self-defrosting.

It is very disappointing that a company such as Igloo, who has been in the business
of keeping things cold for decades, could not do a better job on their small refrigerators.
We have ours cranked all the way to the top setting. It isn't in a hot garage - it is in the
upstairs bedroom. It still can't handle warm temps!

It has been very warm here this week. While we run the A/C endlessly, this little fridge
can't give us a cold drink. All we get are bottles that have a slight, well how should I say this,
a clammy feel to them. You can tell they were in a colder environment than the room, but
the drinks themselves (bottled water, 24 oz pepsi's and juice boxes) are NOT cold.

This has been a major disappointment. I had already thrown the packing material away as it had been
doing a pretty good job and I trusted the brand name. Who knew that it was so dependent on the temperature
in the room as to whether or not you would get a cold drink??

Seriously disappointing, and it will be my LAST Igloo purchase.

UPDATE 08/04/11:
Well, we've now had this three months. So far, we've had lots of drinks that were barely colder
than room temperature. The freezer door (which was NOT the interior that was pictured with the listing
when we bought it - they had the interiors mixed up with a Haier) had so much frost build-up that the door
broke completely off a couple weeks ago. No, we didn't use the freezer - it didn't do anything but freeze that little
mini tray of ice cubes. The freezer pops (those tubes that look like they are filled with koolaid) don't even
freeze in there. I thought hey, maybe with that little freezer section open, the drinks will get colder. Nope!

We have it cranked all the way to 7, the highest this will go. The drinks are not cold by any means.
It does a nice job of keeping things like cheese or fruit, and not too bad on yogurt. However, I wanted
to have COLD drinks this summer, and I am not getting them. We have bottled water and Pepsi in the fridge.
Nothing in a plastic bottle gets very cold at all. We also have some cans of ginger ale in the can rack.
Because of the aluminum, they are a little bit colder than the bottles, but not a lot.

I was putting some more water in there this afternoon, and the inside was so warm and clammy that I checked to
see if it stopped working already. I checked the plugs to be sure it was still plugged in, and it was.
I turned it off for a few minutes to let it rest, then turned it back on. I did not hear a thing. So, I'll check
it tomorrow to see if it died completely. I don't think it did - I just think it cools very poorly and inefficiently.

I COMPLETELY regret this purchase. Steer clear of the Igloo models.
The other brands are a little more (some places, just $30-$50 more), but you might get something that
actually cools your drinks down. This model can't seem to do it. Big disappointment. This is the most
expensive thing I've bought online in a long time, and the joke was on me.

Shame on Igloo for making something so shabby. It looks great on the outside, but can't do the job
you hire it to do. I didn't need another thing taking up floor space - I needed a bedroom refrigerator.

text: Since we bought a new Mr. Coffee Maker the grounds go over the top of the filter and we get grounds in the  coffee pot.

title: So far, so good ....
text:
I purchased two of these to go with my new Keurig Platinum single serve coffee maker. My favorite pre-Keurig coffee isn't available in K-cups, so I had to find something that would work with my own ground coffee.

Read the reviews of the Ekobrew, had a chance to try one at my brother's over Christmas, and decided this was the one I wanted.

I'm not disappointed. So far, it's working great. I found that I need to grind the coffee a bit finer than usual (I use a burr grinder) to get the right strength, but once I'd figured that out, it makes a great cup of coffee.

Cleaning hasn't been as big an issue for me -- I just whack the cup a couple of times gently on the edge of the trash can and 90% of the grounds fall out. A quick wipe with a damp paper towel gets rid of the rest, and after a quick rinse in the sink, the cup is ready to go again.

I haven't had mine long enough to assess durability, but I've seen nothing in the construction/manufacture that would lead me to believe that the cup is anything but well made. I'll update this if that opinion changes.

title: So far, I'm very happy ...
text:
Purchased this in June 2011 when I received an estimate of $380 to fix the ice maker in my fridge. Eventually, I want to replace the fridge, but I'm not ready to do that just now, especially over an ice maker, especially since the rest of the fridge is working just fine!

Saw this on Amazon, and decided to go for it. I've had it for 16 months, and so far it works just fine. Occasionally I have to "reset" it by unplugging it, waiting a few seconds, then plugging it in and restarting it. The ice compartment is not chilled, so the ice tends to melt faster than you might expect, but once the ice level drops below a certain point, it starts making ice again.

And it is FAST. I use the "medium" size setting, and I'd say that within 10 minutes, I'm getting ice.

So far, I'm quite happy with it. I use it probably 3-4 times a week, maybe more in the summer (I live in the Pacific NW, and don't have air conditioning). No problems at all.

title: Not a perfect fit

title: seasoned cold brewer here, lots of info below, brewer works great, easy to use
text:
I have been drinking "cold brew" for well over a decade now. The occasional coffee house would have a cold brew system, and so it was a treat back then to purchase a cup of extra strong and extra smooth coffee. Then I started making it at home. There were no special brew systems yet available. So I would simply take a big pitcher dump a bunch of ground coffee into it, then top it off with water. Cover, let sit for a full day, then either carefully pour into a cup as desired (while trying to keep grounds from falling out), or when I was feeling more motivated I would strain through a cheesecloth. Either way, I had easy cold brewed coffee. YUM.

Forward to the past several years where cold brew coffee has hit critical mass. Most everyone has heard of it, most coffee shops offer it, and many stores sell it. Many cold brew systems are available, just in different styles. Some coffee pot systems are trying to state that they offer cold brew option- but be aware-- cold brew is NOT ICED COFFEE. It is only cold/room temp water on ground coffee, there is no heat applied at any point (save for if you decide to heat it up after the fact). Ok, so.. this brewer:

I have tried a few different types of cold brew systems since my days of dumping loose ground coffee in a pitcher. These days things are a little more stream lined and a tad easier. None of them do anything extra special, it is really just about your preference. It basically breaks down to needing a filter of some sort (can be resuable metal cylinder or paper, like this one has), a vessel to "brew" in. That's it. This system happens to have a little extra in its design. I thought it might be a little much, but I found it pleasant to use, and there was no mess.

There appears to be many parts, but it is super easy to figure out. Instructions are super easy to understand if need be.

Steps:

--The brew container* (see additional info on this part below) is what what you will use to "brew" your coffee. The ratio is 1:8? 8 ounces (1/2 lb) of coffee to about 64 ounces of cold or room temp water. This does not need to be exact. You will not mess up a batch of cold brew if you use a little too much or a little less (though more would be better since you can water it down later if need be). You put course ground coffee into the included paper filter. If not already in base, then place coffee filled bag in side. Put cover on, and set aside on counter or in fridge for 12-24 hours. I usually wait a full day. Sometimes I go longer depending on when I started it. In this case, it was late afternoon, and I kept it on counter for a full day and a half so I could drink some in the morning.

*1. the brew vessel has a lever and stopper you will need to attach. Super quick and easy. Make sure the level is in the stop/closed position before adding water.
*2. Also, there is a 2 pack of carafe filters (small round sponges) that are optional use. I find they are easy to rinse and reuse.

--Once you are done "brewing", put the brewing vessel on top of the grooved pitcher. This is where the lever on the brewing vessel comes in. Push it open. This immediately drains your cold brew into a pourable pitcher. Once the brew vessel is empty, take out bag full of spent coffee and toss it out (OR if you are super thrifty and careful.. perhaps rinse and reuse?). Your pitcher is now full of delicious, smooth, concentrated coffee. The pitcher comes with a lid. The pitcher is of a workable size- easy to hold, small enough to store in fridge, yet holds nearly 2 liters. The size is perfect for storing in the fridge. Indents in the pitcher make it easy to grab/hold.

EDIT: Unlike other brew systems, it dawned on me that I could get another batch "brewing" at any time after the first one. This is because the brew container is separate from the storage container. My other "brewer" is a brewer and pitcher in one. So not until I finish the container (or find a different container to store concentrate in) can I make another batch. With this system, I can simply start another even if storage pitcher is in use (so long as I can access it it after brewing, which I tend to brew for 24-36 hours). Anyway, thought I would come back to add that in since it wasn't an immediate thought when I was using this initially.

"Cold brew" is considered a coffee concentrate. The idea is to have a strong coffee that can withstand being watered down by ice and other coffee additions (cream, syrups, etc) without losing the coffee taste. Or you can drink it straight if you like very strong coffee (I do!). In addition to that, it makes a very smooth coffee. Usually reduces/removes acidity. And lastly, although it seems like it is only consumed cold, it technically can be warmed up to be enjoyed hot. Some people cold brew to reduce the acidity, and then want to still have warm/hot coffee. Go for it. For me, I just really like the added oomph of taste that cold brew coffee makes. I have even noticed that it can make kinda blah coffee even better by being cold brewed. (have you ever purchased a container of coffee and not really liked it? Try cold brewing it-- it just might change things enough to make it palatable!).

Specially about this system: In short, I like it. I first thought it was going to be too many parts to deal with, but I see that the parts it comes with that once they are on, no need to take them off (save for if your brewer needs extra TLC when cleaning). The brew vessel AND a pitcher is more than what is really needed (often I see that a vessel could be the pitcher just by taking bag/filter out)- but this makes it super clean and easy to deal with. I DO like the paper filter over a metal filter in terms of speed of clean up, but some people would prefer not to have excess waste.

This style of system is really going to come down to preference. All the parts on mine look good, work soundly, and I have no problem with using this. With one caveat, the pitcher fits into the brew vessel for easy, compact storage (put lid on pitcher, but find spot for vessel lid). This system comes with TWO PLA bag filters, so you will need more. I do not know what this system costs but it doesn't need to be expensive to be effective. I see that the 25 pack of the filters is $15 (or less if buying 25 pack of regular filters). I have a glass with metal filter system that works well for around $25 although makes half as much at a time). Or just use my old school method of a pitcher with loose coffee in it. :)

If you choose this, know that it absolutely makes a great pitcher of cold brew coffee concentrate. No problems there.

Because I do not know what the price is, I can't automatically recommend this- but I would nudge people in the direction of this style. I personally think it is even easier than the metal filter style, and this makes a decent amount- not too much, but not too little. If it is within reason of other brewers, I would be real pleased. While I normally don't take into consideration price, I do if there are enough of similar products on market-- and knowing that cold brew systems are pretty much all the same except for filter material- that I can comfortably comment on it. Therefor I would normally ask, why would I recommend this over other brewers? That is when price might come into play, along with some other design features. Since this also requires use of paper filter, that is an additional cost. This just comes with two filters, so you would pretty much need to add in the additional cost right away. Say, if I was ordering this I would also order a pack of filters at same time.

What would improve upon product: While the pitcher and lid fits into the brewing vessel for more compact storage, the lid of the brewing vessel has nowhere to go. It could be placed on bottom so all of it just sits on it, or it can be placed on top but there again, it is just resting on it. It doesn't make for perfectly tidy storage. It would work if the brew vessel was taller or the pitcher was shorter-- then the pitcher would nestle down into the brew vessel and the lid could just go on top. The difference doesn't seem like it would be enough to displace water/coffee ratio, but would certainly add to the tidiness of storing it.

Current rating: 5 stars. It totally works as intended, and I have used enough cold brewers of various styles to be extra pleased with this one. I really didn't think it would be better than my simple glass pitcher with metal filter, but the paper filter and ease of separating the brewed coffee into a separate pitcher has impressed me. This system may be my new go-to brewer and I will pass my other one on to a friend. This is a matter of preference for me. Ultimately the rating goes toward the fact that it works well and produces a solid "cold brew" end result. I have been drinking a cup (ok, maybe 3) while writing this so excuse my length. I feel like writing a dissertation on cold brew while simultaneously running full speed on my treadmill. WEEEEEEEEEEe cold brew is fun! :)

title: perfectly fine unbleached compostable coffee filter
text:
"If You Care" products are pretty good. I buy them when I can as I like that they are all unbleached and chlorine free.

The #4 coffee filters work fine in a typical brew system or in use with a pour over style. I had used it in the latter and found that if I pressed the filter with my hand to squeeze out the last of the liquid from the coffee grounds, that it could tear along the seam. I don't think most people would encounter this as most people would use this for coffee to drip into using a machine. But just keep it in mind if you have a need to hand pour hot water over ground coffee- just let gravity do its job, and don't bother to help it along by squeezing out the rest.

It is compostable! After you make your coffee, toss it all into your compost pile!

They seem to make their products with care. Whenever possible I select one of their products over the typical beached or plastic laden product. I am not at all perfect in how I treat my environment, so even if I could do a lot better, I like knowing that t here are companies creating products that help us to have the "Least possible environmental impact" in our day to day lives.

title: Perfectly fine product, does the job with care
text: Every "If You Care" product I have used has been a good product. I am particularly keen on their parchment paper for baking. Unbleached, chlorine free, and better for the environment. As for this product, this is my second package of No 2 Coffee filters, 100 ct. I don't go through them too often, but I use this size when I am brewing a cup of coffee using a collapsible single cup coffee maker (typically used for hotel stays and camping, but occasionally in house too). I think typical coffee makers use No 4. Grounds never seep through it, and my coffee always tastes great. I have no use for the typical white paper filters, and so I am happy to be able to buy this product here as well as in stores. title: Neat little machine, wish I could offer a better score
text:
For what it is, it's a neat little machine and I applaud the company for trying to innovate by creating a small, single barrel washer that isn't $300. Unfortunately, there are draw backs with that reduction in cost.

I did a few loads: underwear/delicates, and mixed items (about an outfit worth).

Positive attributes: Small, washes clothes well, light weight, easy to use, nice medium between a totally manual machine and an automated one.

Negative attributes: water leaks down the sides, (even when water is only filled half way), spinning drum detaches no matter how much or how evenly weighted it is, clothes don't spin out very dry, (they're not dripping wet, but still heavy with water).

text: For reference, my fridge is the LFXC24726S, so if you have this same fridge, these filters will work. I'm simply follow my LG manual on replacing the water filter. There is no need to turn off water. After you change out the filter, be sure to press the "change filter" icon for 3 seconds to reset the 6-month reminder. Lastly, be sure to dispense 2 to 2.5 gallons of water, until your water is clear. It'll be clear after just a gallon, but I like to be sure dispense exactly 2.5. The instructions of this brand says to dispense 2 gallons, LG manual says 2.5. I think either is fine. 5-Stars!

title: High quality, stainless steel, reusable k-cups, not for the Supreme models...
text: I'm sure these are perfectly fine reusable k cups. They are stainless steel and high quality. The problem is I have the K cup supreme machine from Costco. LOL! The supreme uses cups with 5 holes. So please pay attention to what model you have. I'm sure these are 5-Stars.

title: Aesthetically pleasing, practical, and high quality egg holder...
text:
THE GOOD:
--------------
* Spacious, can fit 18 eggs each tray, so 36 total.
* Top cover to protect top level eggs.
* Grab an egg, the next one rolls down.
* Approximately 11 x 8.5 x 5.5 overall dimensions.
* Aesthetically, good looking with rounded corners.
* 7 degrees slop design should allow for proper rolling if you shelf is level.

THE BAD:
------------
* I feel the wall dividers could be a little taller. What I mean is each row, or technically we should say column, can hold 6 eggs. These columns are separated by a very subtle raise or hump. Well, I feel this hump could be a little higher. As is, sometimes an egg from another column can roll over.
* Lastly, depending on how level your fridge or shelves are, you may find that on one shelf, the eggs won't roll, but on another it will. For our fridge, we found that the upper two levels won't roll, but when we put the trays on our bottom level, the eggs rolled nicely.

Overall, we'll go 4-Stars!

title: Maybe not the best package for beginners...
text:
[[VIDEOID:38607a72aabbe686d932e103c44a1d93]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* Quality components from the can housing to the cylinder, valve and fittings.
* Can smash taller 16 oz cans as well.
* Easy to assemble, even without instructions. All you do is look at the product photos and you'll get your answer of what goes where.
* Fun, fun, fun!
* Watch my video for some tips.

THE BAD:
------------
* No manual was in the box. So I asked the seller for it, and they sent me pictures quickly. But it was pointless. Because the "manual" was basically assembly images. I can figure out the assembly, just by looking at their final product photos. What I was looking for was tips, advice, explanations of why this fitting goes here, goes there, etc. Yet still, for a manual that was all about assembly, they leave out the most important part. How do you connect their fittings to an air compressor? Because their fitting is pretty unusual, at least to a newbie. In any case, I uploaded their manual photos for your convenience.
* I still don't know how they want us to connect their can crusher to an air compressor. They obviously have a method in mind, but they don't explain it. They included an extra elbow fitting, and something called an "air pump junction." It's the letter G item in the packet list photo in their listing page. Watch my video to understand my confusion.
* So I had to look at other can crushers on the market to understand how to connect this to an air compressor. What I found out was other sellers include a 1/4" NPT Quick Connect High Flow fitting. So that's what I got, and that's how I got this can crusher going. That's not good when your customers have to go to other sellers to see how things work. LOL!
* The valve included in this package does not automatically reset the cylinder disc. I've seen other can crushers where you push the button, it crushes the can. You let go, and the cylinder resets itself ready for the next crush. With this version, you press the button, it smashes the can, but the cylinder disc does not retract when you let go the button. You have to "Reset" by turning the button/knob clockwise. Then the disc retracts. Not a deal breaker, but just something worth mentioning.
* They are very stingy with the airline tubes. When you connect the airline tubes, you feel a CLICK. For the longer tube, I could not feel a click on both ends. I can feel a click on the end I start, but it wasn't long enough for me to get a good connection on the other end. So I ended up getting a lot of hissing, which means air leaking. So if you need more airline tube, then the search phrase you need to use is, "8mm pneumatic tubing." 8mm is what you want. The long tube that was in the package was 10.25", so I just cut myself something around 11". The shorter one was about 5", so I cut myself something around 6". If you're going to get into pneumatic tools, then these extra tubes you have to buy won't be a waste of money. They'll come in handy in the future.

In conclusion... If you are new to pneumatic can crushers, I do not recommend this listing. It was a lot of headache for a beginner like me. I'm good with tools, so I figure it all out. But if you want to avoid the cost of buying more tubes, and quick connect hose fittings, then I would look elsewhere. This was a 2-Star experience, but I hope that my review will help the seller improve on their product.

title: A complete dryer vent cleaning kit that all homeowners should have...
text: A few yrs ago, our dryer wasn't drying anymore. We reached into the vent that goes out the house, and holy moly guacamole! It was completely stuffed with lint. The previous homeowner probably never cleared their dryer vents. We make it a point to clean it from time to time now, and this kit is going to be very helpful. The 30 ft vent brush is going to be very useful. We've been cleaning with just our hands and some broom sticks, and that's been working fine. We don't technically need this kit, but how can you rate this kit anything  but 5-Stars? It has to be better than broom sticks, right? LOL! 5-Stars.

title: Nice covers that will prevent your washer and dryer from scratches...
text: Works as advertised, but they easily slide, so you need some weight on it, especially if you're going to be storing things in the side pockets. When we first bought our washer & dryer, I wanted something like this to prevent scratches at the top. I never got around to it, that was 12 yrs ago. LOL! I always use old bath towels. Now we finally have something specifically made for this. 5-Stars!

title: Must have to cut down your cleaning time...
text: These oven liners are awesome. We manually cut a hole in it, so that it fits around the stove burners. You can also use them on outdoor grills and bbq. Makes cleaning up so much easier. 5-Stars!

title: Nice solid 4 ft x 10 ft foil duct...
text: The most economical foil duct at your local HD might be the Everbilt brand that is 4 ft x 8 ft long. They also have a 4 ft x 25 ft if you need something longer, but for a dryer vent, 10 ft is more than enough. This looks heavy duty, the clamps feel very strong. We'll see how this works. Looking forward to installing this. 5-stars!

title: Cute and priced just right...
text: Cute and priced just right. We have flat handles, and we also have those handle covers. So Mr. and Mrs. Claus goes on top of the handle covers and everything fits snugly. Cute and you're not breaking the bank for these. 5-Stars!

title: This bin is high quality and very useful...
text: As far as I'm concerned, anything in your house with a metal panel should be taken advantage of with magnetic accessories. The side of the fridge, the side of your washing machines, etc. This bin is plastic, but nice and ridged. The entire back is covered with a magnetic plate, so it will cling to your washing machine super tight. Great item. 5-Stars!

title: Our handles are not round, these work fine...
text: I think these things would look more form fitting if your handles were round. That may just be my mind playing tricks on me. If our handles were round, I might think these look better on the flat handles. LOL! In any case, they get the job done. But up close, the fabric does not feel premium, it's on the cheap side. But you need to consider what you're spending for 6 pieces. The higher quality stuff is more expensive and does not come with 6 pieces. The term, "you get what you pay for" comes to mind. So I'm not going to deduct a star for that. I think this is 5-Stars for the price you're paying.

title: Beautiful quiet wine cooler...
text: About 34 inches high which is pretty much universal in height, so it match the height of our kitchen counters. Very functional and quiet, most importantly, it does what it's suppose to do... keeps the wine cool! Temperature is easy to set, and you can choose between Celsius or Fahrenheit. Removable shelves allow for storage of larger bottles, and the interior lighting is perfect for showcasing of your bottles. A pleasure to use. 5 stars.

title: For my LFXC24726S (No need to shut off water)
text: Love my LFXC24726S, especially the ice. Because it's in a separate and sealed off compartment, the ice has no smell. So when it comes to changing the filters, I want to be on top of it and keep the fresh smell. Changing the air filter was rather easy, but for the water filter, the Aquacrest instructions tell you to turn off the water. I didn't think that was necessary so I read the actual LG manual, and it DID NOT instruct you to turn off the water. After you change out each filter, be sure to press the "change filter" icons for 3 seconds to reset the 6-month reminder. Easy peasy.

title: Quality Ice Machine that Meets the Demands for Multipurpose…
text:
Great for home, parties, and all kinds of events. This unit is well insulated and has ice ready in minutes. We leave this on our counter in the summer because it has an automatic shut down when the ice container is full. We also use this for outside church events and its capacity of 24 lbs of ice is more than sufficient for groups of 100 people to fill their cups with ice. The tall slim design is great for any countertop and the quality is top notch. Highly Recommend!!!

title: Flawless Version 2.0 Works Great!!!
text:
We don't have any ice maker in our freezer and no place for trays. So, this is the solution. We run it all the time. It actually saves on soda and other beverages with the children. The ice cubes are not rock hard. It is more like shaved ice in cube form.

We had a smaller Ice maker that took up less counter space, but it didn't keep the ice as cold as this one. So, the ice would melt quickly and the machine had to keep running. This one seems more energy efficient. The side water tank makes this a no hassle ice machine.

text:
